<span id="3650"></span>

<div id="answer-container-3650" class="answer">

<table style="width:100%;"><colgroup><col style="width: 50%" /><col style="width: 50%" /></colgroup><tbody><tr class="odd"><td style="width: 30px; vertical-align: top"><div class="vote-buttons"><span id="post-3650-upvote" class="ajax-command post-vote up" rel="nofollow" title="I like this post (click again to cancel)"> </span><div id="post-3650-score" class="post-score" title="current number of votes">1</div><span id="post-3650-downvote" class="ajax-command post-vote down" rel="nofollow" title="I dont like this post (click again to cancel)"> </span></div></td><td><div class="item-right"><div class="answer-body"><p>239.255.255.250 is a multicast address (not a broadcast, that would be 255.255.255.255.) reserved for Simple Service Discovery Protocol (SSDP). So nothing fancy, just the station with IP 192.168.0.1 looking for services offered by other nodes.</p><p>For more information about SSDP you might want to take a look at <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Service_Discovery_Protocol">Wikipedia</a> for example.</p></div><div class="answer-controls post-controls"></div><div class="post-update-info-container"><div class="post-update-info post-update-info-user"><p>answered <strong>20 Apr '11, 11:58</strong></p><img src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c578ba2967741f25aebd6afef702f432?s=32&amp;d=identicon&amp;r=g" class="gravatar" width="32" height="32" alt="Jasper&#39;s gravatar image" /><p><span>Jasper ♦♦</span><br />
<span class="score" title="23806 reputation points"><span>23.8k</span></span><span title="5 badges"><span class="badge1">●</span><span class="badgecount">5</span></span><span title="51 badges"><span class="silver">●</span><span class="badgecount">51</span></span><span title="284 badges"><span class="bronze">●</span><span class="badgecount">284</span></span><br />
<span class="accept_rate" title="Rate of the user&#39;s accepted answers">accept rate:</span> <span title="Jasper has 263 accepted answers">18%</span></p></div><div class="post-update-info post-update-info-edited"><p><span> edited <strong>20 Apr '11, 12:36</strong> </span></p></div></div><div id="comments-container-3650" class="comments-container"><span id="3652"></span><div id="comment-3652" class="comment"><div id="post-3652-score" class="comment-score"></div><div class="comment-text"><p>Thanks for the reply.</p><p>I just noticed that the packet is originating from my router's IP address and not my machine. Sorry for the confusion but why does it need to broadcast so often as I can see many of these packets small number of bytes are being sent out ? What kind of services is it looking for by the way ? Can you give any links to resources that might provide any information ?</p><p>Best Regards</p><p>Victor</p></div><div id="comment-3652-info" class="comment-info"><span class="comment-age">(20 Apr '11, 12:21)</span> <span class="comment-user userinfo">victor43</span></div></div><span id="3655"></span><div id="comment-3655" class="comment"><div id="post-3655-score" class="comment-score"></div><div class="comment-text"><p>I added a link for you in my original answer.</p></div><div id="comment-3655-info" class="comment-info"><span class="comment-age">(20 Apr '11, 12:37)</span> <span class="comment-user userinfo">Jasper ♦♦</span></div></div><span id="3656"></span><div id="comment-3656" class="comment"><div id="post-3656-score" class="comment-score"></div><div class="comment-text"><p>Many thanks for the link.</p><p>I did have one question more. How do you filter out certain packets like the one above SSDP protocol. In other words I want don't want them to appear in the displayed output to the user. I could not find the protocol SSDP under Enabled Protocols under the Analyze menu item.</p><p>Victor</p></div><div id="comment-3656-info" class="comment-info"><span class="comment-age">(20 Apr '11, 13:04)</span> <span class="comment-user userinfo">victor43</span></div></div><span id="3657"></span><div id="comment-3657" class="comment"><div id="post-3657-score" class="comment-score"></div><div class="comment-text"><p>I was able to disable the resolve the issue by just googling the answer. IF anyone wants to know you can simply disable the multicast protocol from your router's interface for UPnP.</p></div><div id="comment-3657-info" class="comment-info"><span class="comment-age">(20 Apr '11, 13:17)</span> <span class="comment-user userinfo">victor43</span></div></div></div><div id="comment-tools-3650" class="comment-tools"></div><div class="clear"></div><div id="comment-3650-form-container" class="comment-form-container"></div><div class="clear"></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
